questions.question: Which artery is involved in Lateral medullary syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery Explanation: The occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome. Wallenberg syndrome: Also known as Lateral medullary syndrome Pathology: Blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus. Damage to the lateral segment of the medulla posterior to the inferior olivary nucleus. Clinical manifestation: Anatomical location Presenting clinical feature Nucleus ambiguous gives fibers to IX, X, and XI cranial nerves Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx Spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss Lateral spinothalamic tract Contralateral body pain and temperature loss Vestibular nuclei Vertigo Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum Ipsilateral ataxia Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis

questions.question: Match the following: A) Glossopharyngeal nerve 1) Shrugging of shoulder B) Spinal accessory nerve 2) Touch sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue two-thirds of the tongue
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3 Explanation: Correct Option is: A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3 A) Glossopharyngeal nerve 2) Touch sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue B) Spinal accessory nerve 1) Shrugging of shoulder C) Facial nerve 4) Taste from the anterior two third of the tongue D) Mandibular nerve 3) Chewing Cranial nerves: Nerve CN Function Type Olfactory I Smell (only CN without thalamic relay to cortex) Sensory Optic II Sight Sensory Oculomotor III Eye movement (SR, IR, MR, IO), pupillary constriction (sphincter pupillae), accommodation (ciliary muscle), eyelid opening (levator palpebrae) Motor Trochlear IV Eye movement (SO) Motor Trigeminal V Mastication, facial sensation (ophthalmic, maxillary, mandibular divisions), somatosensation from anterior 2/3 of tongue, dampening loud noises (tensor tympani) Both Abducens VI Eye movement (LR) Motor Facial VII Facial movement, eye closing (orbicularis oculi), auditory volume modulation (stapedius), taste from anterior 2/3 of tongue (chorda tympani), lacrimation, salivation (submandibular and sublingual glands) Both Vestibulocochlear VIII Hearing, balance Sensory Glossopharyngeal IX Taste and sensation from posterior 1/3 of tongue, swallowing, salivation (parotid gland), monitoring carotid body and sinus chemo- and baroreceptors, elevation of pharynx/larynx (stylopharyngeus) Both Vagus X Taste from supraglottic region, swallowing, soft palate elevation, midline uvula, talking, cough reflex, parasympathetics to thoracoabdominal viscera, monitoring aortic arch chemo- and baroreceptors Both Accessory XI Head turning, shoulder shrugging (SCM, trapezius) Motor Hypoglossal XII Tongue movement Motor Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470353/

questions.question: The marked structure relays efferents to which nucleus of the thalamus? [
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anterior nucleus of thalamus Explanation: The marked structure is the fornix. Fornix is the major efferent tract of the hippocampus. The fornix sends efferents to the mammillary bodies, and the mammillothalamic tract connects the mammillary bodies to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. This pathway is part of the Papez circuit, involved in memory and emotional processing. Thalamic Nuclei and their Connection: Anterior nucleus Receives input from hypothalamic mammillary nuclei via mammillothalamic tract. Receives input from the hippocampus via fornix. Projects fibers to the cingulate gyrus. Dorsomedial nucleus Part of the limbic system. Lesion results in memory loss (Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome). Intralaminar nuclei Receives input from the reticular formation. Projects fibers to the neocortex. Sends fibers to other thalamic nuclei (unlike other thalamic nuclei, which project to different cortical areas). Dorsal tier nucleus Lateral dorsal nucleus : Posterior extension of the anterior nucleus. Pulvinar : Largest thalamic nucleus. Receives input from the lateral and medial geniculate bodies. Integrates visual and auditory input. Ventral tier nucleus Ventral anterior nucleus : Receives input from globus pallidus and substantia nigra. Projects fibers to the motor cortex. Ventral posterior nucleus : Contains three subnuclei: Ventral posterolateral (VPL) : Receives input from spinothalamic tracts and medial lemniscus. Ventral posteromedial (VPM) : Receives input from trigeminothalamic tracts. Ventral posterior inferior (VPI) : Receives input from vestibular nuclei. Lateral nucleus of thalamus (Option B): The lateral nucleus functions as the hunger center, promoting eating when stimulated, while its destruction leads to starvation. Ventro-postero-lateral nucleus of thalamus (Option C): The ventro-postero-lateral nucleus of the thalamus processes sensations like pain, vibration, proprioception, and light touch from the spinothalamic tract and dorsal column pathways. Posterior nucleus of the thalamus (Option D): The posterior nucleus aids in thermoregulation by

questions.question: Which of the following structures is derived from the marked point in the given image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ribs Explanation: Structures derived from the paraxial mesoderm include the somites. Somites are bilaterally paired blocks of mesoderm that form on either side of the neural tube during early embryonic development. The somites give rise to various structures in the embryo, including the axial skeleton (such as vertebrae), skeletal muscles, and the dermis of the skin. Intraembryonic Mesoderm/ Secondary Mesoderm: Formed by the proliferation of cells from the primitive streak. Separates the ectoderm and endoderm except in specific regions that remain bilaminar throughout life: Prochordal plate (future oral cavity) Cloacal membrane (future anal and urogenital openings) Midline caudal to the prochordal plate Formation of intraembryonic mesoderm. (B) is a section along axis in (A) Subdivisions: 1. Paraxial Mesoderm 2. Lateral Plate Mesoderm 3. Intermediate Mesoderm Located on either side of the notochord and becomes thick. It forms a thinner layer located laterally. A longitudinal strip found between the paraxial and lateral plate mesoderm. It forms: Somitomeres: Form mesoderm and muscles of the head and jaw. Somites: Form midline axial skeleton, skeletal muscles and dermis of back. It forms: Somatopleuric (parietal) layer: Forms connective tissue of the body wall and limbs, such as appendicular skeleton bones , muscles and dermis of periphery. Splanchnopleuric (visceral) layers: Forms connective tissue and smooth muscle layers of the gut, cardiac muscle and the circulatory system. It forms: Urinary and genital systems. Somites: Paraxial mesoderm becomes segmented to form 42-44 pairs of somites develop on either side of the neural tube and notochord. Appear between the 20th and 30th day, marking the 4th week as the somite period. Somite Structure: Sclerotome: Ventromedial part; forms vertebral column and ribs. Dermatome: Lateral part; forms dermis of skin and subcutaneous tissue. Myotome: Intermediate part; forms striated muscle. Kidneys (Option B): Kidneys are the derivatives of the intermediate mesoderm. Dorsal root ganglion (Option C): Dorsal root ganglia are derived from the neural crest cells. Parietal pleura (Option D): The pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities, housing vital organs, originate from the lateral plate mesoderm during embryonic development.

questions.question: What is the blood supply of the marked area in the given image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery Explanation: The highlighted structure is the inferior cerebellar peduncle, a white matter bundle linking the medulla oblongata to the cerebellum. It is mainly supplied by the Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA), a branch of the vertebral artery. Blood supply of various parts of brain: Structure Blood Supply Medulla Anterior spinal artery Posterior spinal artery Posterior inferior cerebellar artery Medullary branch from basilar artery Pons Anterior inferior cerebellar artery Pontine branch from basilar artery Superior cerebellar artery Midbrain Posterior cerebral artery Superior cerebellar artery Thalamus Posterior communicating artery Posterior cerebral artery Cerebellum Posterior inferior cerebellar artery Anterior inferior cerebellar artery Superior cerebellar artery Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (Option B): The anterior inferior cerebral artery (AICA) a branch of the basilar artery, supplies blood to the anteroinferior cerebellum, middle cerebellar peduncle, and inferolateral pons. Superior cerebellar artery (Option C): Superior cerebellar artery (SCA) supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, superior and middle cerebellar peduncles, and the lower midbrain. Posterior Cerebral Artery (Option D): The Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) provides blood supply to the occipital cortex, inferior and medial temporal cortices, thalamus, and rostral midbrain. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7646108/#:~:text

questions.question: Arrange the neural columns in medial-to-lateral order in the floor of fourth ventricle 1. Special somatic afferent 2. Special visceral afferent 3. General somatic afferent 4. General somatic afferent
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) GVA, SVA, GSA, SSA Explanation: The neural columns are arranged in the alar lamina of the developing spinal cord in the following order: Medial to lateral: GVE → SVE → SE → GVA → SVA → GSA → SSA Functional Columns and Nuclei of Cranial Nerve: Sulcus limitans divides the mantle zone of brain stem and spinal cord into anterior motor efferent basal plate and posterior sensory afferent alar plate. Afferents and efferents from brainstem:

questions.question: The patient presented with ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body. Which artery is involved in the syndrome based on clinical features?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Posterior inferior cerebellar artery Explanation: The patient's presentation with ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body is suggestive lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome. The occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome also called the Wallenberg syndrome. Wallenberg syndrome: Also known as Lateral medullary syndrome Pathology: Blockage of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus. Damage to the lateral segment of the medulla posterior to the inferior olivary nucleus. Clinical manifestation: Anatomical location Presenting clinical feature Nucleus ambiguous gives fibers to IX, X, and XI cranial nerves Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx Spinal nucleus and spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve Ipsilateral facial pain and temperature loss Lateral spinothalamic tract Contralateral body pain and temperature loss Vestibular nuclei Vertigo Inferior cerebellar peduncle, spino cerebellar tracts, and part of cerebellum Ipsilateral ataxia Sympathetic fibres descend from the hypothalamus to cells in the lateral horn of spinal cord Horner’s syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis, and anhydrosis Superior cerebellar artery (Option B) : The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior portion of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain. While it can lead to symptoms like ataxia or vertigo, it doesn’t typically cause the specific signs described (ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, Horner's syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature in the body). Basilar artery (Option C): NA blockage in the basilar artery can lead to locked-in syndrome or other pontine deficits Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) (Option D) : AICA strokes can cause symptoms like vertigo, ataxia, and facial weakness.

questions.question: What is the vertebral level shown by the arrow in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) L4-L5 Explanation: If the blue line is at the L4-L5 level, then this option is correct. L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts. L2-L3 (Option A): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. The L2-L3 level would be higher up on the spine, and if the blue line is visibly at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer. L5-S1 (Option C): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L5-S1 refers to the intervertebral space between the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5) and the first sacral vertebra (S1), which is lower down the spine. If the blue line is at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer. L3-L4 (Option D): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L3-L4 refers to the intervertebral space between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). If the blue line is visible at the L4-L5 level, then this option is not the correct answer.

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with a swelling below the ear and complains of pain in the lobule of the ear. The patient also reports difficulty in completely closing the left eye and experiences trouble while eating food. What nerve is most likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Facial nerve Explanation: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) controls facial expressions, including eye closure and smiling. Damage to it can cause weakness or paralysis in these muscles. Additionally, it regulates muscles for eating and swallowing, which aligns with the patient's eating difficulties. External Ear consists of two main parts: Pinna (Auricle) External Auditory Meatus Aspects Auricle (Pinna) External Auditory Meatus Composition Elastic cartilage, except lobule (fibrofatty tissue) Cartilaginous part (Outer 1/3) with hair and ceruminous glands Bony part (Inner 2/3), with thin skin continuous with the tympanic membrane, lacks hair and glands. Parts Concha (Depression leading to the external meatus) Helix (Prominent rim with anterior and posterior limbs) Antihelix ( Parallel ridge to the helix) Tragus & Antitragus (Separated by inter-tragic notch) Cymba Conchae (Above crus of helix) Lobule (Soft, fleshy part below antitragus) Nerve Supply Lateral Surface Lower third: Great auricular nerve (C2, C3) Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3) Concha: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) (Alderman’s Nerve) Medial Surface Lower third: Great auricular nerve Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2) Roof & Anterior Wall: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3) Floor & Posterior Wall: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) Clinical Relevance McEwen’s triangle (Cymba Conchae) It is a surgical landmark on the temporal bone to locate the mastoid antrum. Furuncles (cartilaginous part) susceptible to infections Greater Auricular nerve (Option A): Damage to this nerve might result in altered sensation around the ear, but it wouldn't explain the symptoms mentioned in the case. Auriculotemporal nerve (Option B): provides sensation to the external ear and part of the scalp. However, it doesn't control facial movement, eye closure, or eating functions. Vagus nerve (Option D): While damage to the vagus nerve might cause some difficulties in swallowing and speech, it would not explain the specific symptoms of facial muscle weakness, inability to close the eye, or earlobe pain described in the case.

questions.question: Which pathway provides afferent fibers to the mammillary body, a structure located beneath the brain's surface?
questions.explanation: limbic system, including its connection with the mammillary body. The mammillary bodies receive afferent fibers via the fornix, which connects the hippocampus (a critical component of the limbic system) to the mammillary bodies. Incorrect Options: Option A - Corpus callosum: The corpus callosum connects the brain's two hemispheres but isn't directly involved in the afferent pathways to the mammillary body. Option B - Thalamus: While the thalamus is interconnected with the mammillary body through neural circuits, it does not directly send afferent fibers to the mammillary body. Option C - Pituitary gland: Although pituitary gland has connections with the hypothalamus, it does not send afferent fibers to the mammillary body.

questions.question: Which muscle among the following is not innervated by the structure labeled as A?
questions.explanation: A, which is the oculomotor nerve. Incorrect Option: Option A - The oculomotor nerve innervates the superior rectus muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eye and medially rotating it. Option C - The oculomotor nerve innervates the medial rectus muscle, which is responsible for adducting the eye (moving it inward towards the midline). Option D - The oculomotor nerve innervates the LPS muscle, which is responsible for elevating the upper eyelid. Reference: .

questions.question: The nerve of the second branchial arch is?
questions.explanation: embryonic development, the branchial arches form the basic structure of the face and neck, and each branchial arch is associated with specific cranial nerves. The second branchial arch is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Incorrect Options: Option B - Glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve is associated with the third branchial arch Option C - Trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V): The trigeminal nerve is associated with the first branchial arch Option D - Vagal nerve (cranial nerve X): The vagal nerve is associated with the fourth and sixth branchial arches , not the second arch. Reference: .

questions.question: A 55-year-old man is accompanied by his wife to the Neurology OPD. His wife expressed concern about her husband's condition and they were directed to this facility by a local doctor. According to the doctor's note, the patient is unable to repeat spoken words, but can comprehend them and respond appropriately by nodding. The patient also experiences difficulty in naming people and writing. The doctor referred the patient to a specialized facility for a CT brain scan. As the intern on duty, you would inform the Chief Medical Officer (CMO) that this condition could be indicative of a brain lesion in which specific area?
questions.explanation: writing, yet intact comprehension of spoken language, suggests Conduction Aphasia. It's caused by a disconnection between language centers in the brain, possibly affecting the Arcuate Fasciculus. This white matter tract links Broca's area (speech production) with Wernicke's area (language comprehension). Damage here can lead to symptoms like those described in conduction aphasia, where patients struggle to repeat words or phrases accurately despite understanding them. Incorrect Options: Option B - Anterior commissure: The anterior commissure is involved in the connection between the two cerebral hemispheres but is not typically associated with the specific language symptoms described. Option C - Corpus callosum: Damage to the corpus callosum can result in a variety of symptoms but is not specifically associated with the language deficits described. Option D - Fornix: The fornix is a white matter structure involved in memory processes but is not typically associated with the language symptoms described. Reference: .

questions.question: The structure indicated in the provided image originates from the
questions.explanation: fornix. The hippocampus is a curved structure located in the medial temporal lobe and is closely associated with memory and spatial navigation. The fornix arises from the hippocampus and serves as the major output pathway from this structure. Incorrect Options: Option A - Mamillary body: The mamillary bodies, found in the hypothalamus, are involved in regulating physiological processes. Although the fornix is connected to them, it doesn't originate from the mamillary bodies. Option C - Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a central relay for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex. While it connects with many brain structures, it isn't the source of the fornix. Option D - Amygdala: The amygdala, deep in the temporal lobe, processes emotions and memory. While linked to the hippocampus and part of the limbic system, it isn't where the fornix originates. Reference: .

questions.question: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient?
questions.explanation: controls speech production by coordinating motor movements. Damage to this area can cause Broca's aphasia or expressive aphasia, characterized by difficulty forming words and producing fluent speech. While speech is impaired, comprehension usually remains intact. Incorrect Options: Option A - Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in receptive aphasia or Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by impaired language comprehension and fluent but nonsensical speech. Option C - Heschl's area: Heschl's area, the primary auditory cortex in the superior temporal gyrus, processes auditory information. Damage here isn't likely to cause the described symptoms. Option D - Striate area: The striate area is involved in visual processing and is not directly associated with language production or comprehension. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.explanation: movement, is not primarily processed by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Proprioceptive information from the face and head is primarily conveyed through other sensory pathways, such as the proprioceptive fibers within cranial nerves like the facial nerve (CN VII) and glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). Incorrect Options: Option A - Temperature: Temperature sensations from the face and head are transmitted through the trigeminal nerve and processed in the spinal nucleus. Option B - Pain: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve processes pain sensations from the face and head. Option C - Touch: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve also processes touch sensations from the face and head. It receives sensory input related to light touch, pressure, and tactile sensations.

questions.question: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram.
questions.explanation: wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus as the structure marked as ‘C’ corresponds to the pituitary gland. Incorrect Options: Choices A, C, D are incorrect as they are matched with the respective structures in the image. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the destination of the relayed signals from the Purkinje cells in the cerebellum?
questions.explanation: dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei located within the cerebellum. It receives input from the Purkinje cells located in the cerebellar cortex. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a crucial role in motor coordination and planning. Incorrect Options: Option A - Caudate nucleus: The caudate nucleus is a part of the basal ganglia, which is involved in motor control. It does not directly receive input from the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Option B - Lentiform nucleus:The lentiform nucleus, part of the basal ganglia, includes the globus pallidus and putamen. Like the caudate nucleus, it doesn't directly relay signals from Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.. Option D - Red nucleus: The red nucleus in the midbrain aids in motor coordination, receiving input from the cerebellum, but not specifically from Purkinje cells. Its primary output targets the spinal cord and brainstem. Reference: .

questions.question: Please identify the structure indicated in the image below.
questions.explanation: scan as a larger bulge in the brainstem. In a sagittal section, the pons may appear as a larger, oval-shaped structure located below the midbrain and above the medulla oblongata. Incorrect Options: Option A - Midbrain: In a sagittal section, the midbrain may appear as a small round structure located above the pons and below the thalamus. It is located anterior to the fourth ventricle and has a distinctive "butterfly" shape on axial views. Option C - Medulla oblongata: The medulla oblongata is visible on an MRI or CT scan as a tapering structure that connects the brainstem to the spinal cord. In a sagittal section, the medulla oblongata may appear as a smaller, pointed structure located below the pons. The medulla oblongata appears as a tapering structure that connects the brainstem to the spinal cord and is located at the bottom of the brainstem. Option D - Spinal cord: The spinal cord is located within the spinal canal, which is formed by the vertebrae of the spine. In a sagittal section, the spinal cord may appear as a central canal surrounded by white matter and gray matter. Reference: PrepLadder Notes

questions.question: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.explanation: Incorrect Options: Option B - Posterior: The posterior fontanelle close, usually by the age of 2 to 3 months. Therefore, it is not the last fontanelle to close. Option C - Occipital: The occipital fontanelle is not a term used to describe a fontanelle. The occipital region of the skull refers to the back of the head, but it does not specifically indicate the presence of a fontanelle. Option D - Mastoid: The mastoid fontanelle close, usually by the age of 1 year Therefore, it is not the last fontanelle to close. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not a part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column?
questions.explanation: eye movement, specifically the downward and inward rotation of the eye. It is part of the general somatic efferent column. It does not have a role in special visceral afferent functions such as taste or smell. Incorrect Options: Option A - Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) carries taste sensations from the front two-thirds of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column. Option C - Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries taste sensations from the epiglottis and lower pharynx to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column. Option D - Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) transmits taste sensations from the back one-third of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius via the special visceral afferent (SVA) column. Reference: .

questions.question: Broca’s area is situated in the_________.
questions.explanation: region of the brain associated with language production and speech articulation. Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. It is specifically involved in language production and speech articulation, playing a crucial role in the ability to express oneself verbally. Incorrect Options : Option B - Superior temporal gyrus: The superior temporal gyrus handles auditory processing and language comprehension but is not where Broca's area is located. Option C - Angular gyrus:The angular gyrus, in the parietal lobe, aids in reading, writing, and math, but it is not the precise location of Broca's area. . Option D - Postcentral gyrus: The postcentral gyrus handles somatosensory data like touch and pressure, not speech production like Broca's area. Reference: .

questions.question: Identify the structure marked B in the image given below:
questions.explanation: system and is involved in memory and spatial navigation. It connects various parts of the brain, including the hippocampus and mammillary bodies. This is the structure marked as B in the image. Incorrect Option: Option A - Pineal gland The pineal gland is a small endocrine gland located near the center of the brain, but it is not the structure marked in the image. Option B - Falx cerebri The falx cerebri is a fold of dura mater that separates the two cerebral hemispheres. It is not the structure marked in the image. Option D - Pituitary gland The pituitary gland is an endocrine gland located at the base of the brain, but it is not the structure marked in the image.

questions.question: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.explanation: The internal capsule is composed of projection fibers passing to and from the brainstem and the cerebral cortex. It consists of 3 parts: an anterior limb, a posterior limb, and a genu. Projection fibers are neural fibers that transmit signals between the cerebral cortex and lower brain regions or the spinal cord. They carry sensory information from the peripheral nervous system to the brain (ascending pathways) and motor commands from the brain to the peripheral nervous system (descending pathways). Incorrect Option: Option A - Short association: Short association fibers are neural connections that link different areas within the same cerebral hemisphere. In the internal capsule image, they wouldn't stand out prominently as it's primarily composed of projection fibers. Option B - Long association: Long association fibers connect different cortical areas within the same hemisphere and allow for communication and integration between distant regions. They would not be expected to be specifically marked in the image of the internal capsule. Option D - Commissural: Commissural fibers are neural fibers that connect corresponding areas in the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing for communication and integration between the left and right hemispheres.

questions.question: Failure of closure of rostral neuropore at 25th day leads to?
questions.explanation: embryonic development leads to the condition known as anencephaly . Anencephaly is a severe congenital malformation characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain and skull. Incorrect Options: Option A - Hydranencephaly: Hydranencephaly, marked by near-total or complete absence of cerebral hemispheres, isn't specifically due to the failure of rostral neuropore closure. Option B - Rachischisis: Rachischisis is a severe type of spina bifida where the neural tube doesn't close along the spine's entire length, not involving rostral neuropore closure. Option D - Spina bifida: Spina bifida, involves incomplete neural tube closure, leading to spinal cord defects, but it's not directly linked to rostral neuropore closure failure.

questions.question: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by:
questions.explanation: that supply blood to the brain. It arises from the internal carotid artery and provides blood supply to the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemispheres. It also supplies blood to the fornix, which is part of the limbic system. Incorrect Options: Option A - Vertebral artery: The vertebral arteries, from the subclavian arteries, ascend through vertebrae to nourish the back of the brain, but they don't directly supply the fornix. Option B - Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid arteries are major arteries that supply blood to the anterior part of the brain, but they do not directly supply the fornix. Option D - Middle cerebral artery: The middle cerebral artery, a major branch of the internal carotid artery, feeds blood to the lateral parts of the cerebral hemispheres but doesn't directly nourish the fornix. Reference: .

questions.question: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below causes?
questions.explanation: situated in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. Lesions here result in contralateral hemiplegia, where damage affects motor fibers crossing over to the opposite side of the body. These fibers form the corticospinal tracts, transmitting motor signals from the brain to the spinal cord and muscles. Incorrect Options: Option B - Ataxia refers to a lack of coordination of voluntary muscle movements. Lesions in other areas of the brain, such as the cerebellum, are more commonly associated with ataxia. Option C - Tinnitus, the perception of ringing or noise in the ears, is usually linked to auditory system problems like inner ear or auditory nerve damage, not lesions in the medullary pyramids. Option D - Facial palsy is usually due to lesions in the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) from the pons, not the medullary pyramids. Reference: .

questions.question: A woman presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria, and gait ataxia. MRI revealed an acute infarct in the right dorsolateral medulla. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: of brainstem. Symptoms: Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), dysarthria (difficulty speaking), gait ataxia (unsteadiness while walking). Dorsolateral medulla: Controls various functions; symptom severity varies based on infarct location and extent Incorrect Options: Option A - Dejerine's anterior bulbar syndrome: Rare condition from damage to lower part of brainstem. Symptoms: Paralysis of muscles for chewing, swallowing, and speaking. Different from Wallenberg syndrome, which involves dorsolateral medulla specifically. Option C - Babinski-Nageotte syndrome: Babinski-Nageotte syndrome is a term that is not commonly used in medical literature. It may refer to a combination of symptoms involving weakness or paralysis of the arm and leg on one side of the body, along with abnormal reflexes. However, this is not a well-defined syndrome Option D - Weber syndrome: Results from midbrain damage, leading to weakness or paralysis on one side of the body. Other symptoms: Abnormal eye movements. Reference: Prepladder Notes
